results.title: The Venice Gondola Pageant
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Once a year the gondoliers of Venice compete for the honour of being the fastest gondolier. This video looks at all of the pageantry which accompanies this event as well as touring Venice itself, describing a little of its history and crafts, including the construction of the gondolas themselves, and what it is like to live there.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Sing Out for Wales
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
The Royal National Eisteddfod is an annual celebration of the Welsh language and culture, particularly as expressed in mass choirs and poetry. The miserable weather conditions of this particular Eisteddfod do little to dampen the enthusiasm of the participants as they gather to elect the prize-winning bard of the year.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Dutch Pirates Are Heroes
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Every April, in the Dutch city of Brielle, the community holds a festival of dance, wine and song to commemorate the 1572 victory of Flemish pirates and beggars over the invading Spanish ships. The festival involves a procession through the main square and a re-creation of the battle between the pirates and the Spanish sailors.

results.title: Ghost of the Spanish Warrior
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
The Moors and Christians festival of Alicoy in Alicante, Spain celebrates the defeat of the Moors by Christians after 500 years of occupation which left an indelible mark on Spanish culture and architecture. Led by a boy representing St. George, the town’s patron saint, groups of ‘crusaders’ stage a symbolic battle against the ‘moors’.

results.title: A Day for Being Irish
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Every year since 1606 the town of Ballycastle in County Antrim, Northern Ireland has held the Lammas Fair to which people come to trade, barter and generally have a good time. Originally the fair was set up for the Scottish overlords of the time to trade their horses for black cattle and other goods that they needed. The nearby islanders of Rathlin also participate in the fair by selling seaweed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: A World of Festivals
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description: A series which captures the appeal, colour and cultural tradition of European festivals and their locations. The rituals, forms of behaviour, dress, music, folklore and fun behind each event are explored, so that a fascinating and colourful picture of other societies’ culture and traditions is presented.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Japan - Land of the Rising Sun
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Part 1: Tokyo and Yokohama - In Tokyo, one of the largest cities in the world, Japan’s traditional past mixes with the streamlined present. The bustling sophistication of the Ginza, with its renowned department stores and shopping, contrast with the historic Imperial Palace. Yokohama has a famous harbour and colourful history. Yokohama’s many attractions include its historic Chinatown, the Marine Tower, the beautiful Sankeien Gardens, and the amazing City of Tomorrow. Part 2: Kyoto, Hakone, Okayame and Kanazawa. Japan’s former capital, the ancient city of Kyoto with its palaces, wonderful temples and delightful parks is full of charm. Famed Gion Corner with its introduction to Japanese arts and theatre and the talent of the Geisha. Visit the Heian Shrine to see a Japanese wedding and contemplate the stunning Golden Pavilion of the Kinkakuji Temple. History and beauty combine to greet twenty million visitors to Hakone’s many attractions include the celebrated Open Air Museum. Okayama, Kurashiki and Kanazawa have many attractions to offer including castles, museums, beautiful gardens and markets and arts and crafts. Rated: G

results.title: India: Delhi and Agra, Rajasthan and Kashmir
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Delhi, capital of India, and steeped in history, is the perfect start to any trip to India, the land of fascinating contrasts. Visit the bustling bazaars, the Red Fort, former citadel of the Moghul emperors…and New Delhi with its stately structures and underground markets, dungeons and sprawling ruins. Agra home of the Taj Mahal. Stroll down Agra’s exotic streets and marvel at its attractions…the forts, palaces and tombs of past emperors. Rajasthan and Kashmir - enchanting palaces, impregnable forts, uncompromising deserts and tranquil lakes. Kashmir - overlooked by the mighty Himalayas. Its wonderful mountain streams, forests and beautiful lakes with their famous houseboats. Moghul gardens and romantic architecture, make Kashmir the Jewel in the Crown of India.

results.title: China
results.creator_credit: Colin Baker, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Cinegroup
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
China is the world’s longest continuous civilisation and the country is rich with ancient artefacts and sites. The opening of China to tourism by its Communist rulers has meant that this nation of over one billion people is now a popular tourist attraction. This video begins in the capital of Beijing where we witness the marvels of the Forbidden City and the Temple of Heaven. From there we travel to Xian and follow the Silk Road to Lanzhou, and visit a Buddhist monastery. From there onwards we travel across the stark Gobi Desert. This video is an excellent introduction to the landscape and vast diversity of China.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Baker, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Cinegroup
results.description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
China is the world’s longest continuous civilisation and the country is rich with ancient artefacts and sites. The opening of China to tourism by its Communist rulers has meant that this nation of over one billion people is now a popular tourist attraction. This video begins in the capital of Beijing where we witness the marvels of the Forbidden City and the Temple of Heaven. From there we travel to Xian and follow the Silk Road to Lanzhou, and visit a Buddhist monastery. From there onwards we travel across the stark Gobi Desert. This video is an excellent introduction to the landscape and vast diversity of China.
